dialogueacts.text: the method that we usually use in the user interface design is that we need to look at what people like and what people don't like about existing products .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: So , in our case , existing remote controls .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: And then , what the good ideas are ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: and what the bad ideas are ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: and why they're bad and good ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: We seem to have intuitions about why things are good or things are bad ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: but when you look , technically , at how it works , sometimes that's not the case .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: Then we need to decide what functionalities we really want to keep ,
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: 'cause that'll feed into both Ed's work and Christine's work .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: Um and then what the remote control should look like ,
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: obviously , once we've got a good idea of what the functionalities are .
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: in terms of the functionalities that we need , you obviously need to be able to turn the T_V_ on and off .
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: You need to change channels , both by directly going to a specific channel or by channel surfing .
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: You need to be able to control the volume
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: and then control any menus on the T_V_ to regulate contrast or whatever .
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: the problems that people have expressed is that there's too many buttons on remote controls , in general .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: The buttons <disfmarker> it's not clear what they're supposed to do .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: Um often , you need to know specific button sequences <vocalsound> to get certain functionalities done ,
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: um which you don't necessarily always remember , especially if it's a functionality that you don't use very often .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: And that the buttons are too small .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: So my personal preferences are to keep the number of buttons to a limit , or to a minimum ,
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: make frequently used buttons bigger and more strategically placed , so like the on button being really obvious one , the channel changing and the volume ,
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: and to keep the design basically sleek and simple .
dialogueacts.label: sug

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: Which , I think ties into what Christine and Ed have both said fairly reasonably .
dialogueacts.label: inf

dialogueacts.speaker: C
dialogueacts.text: I don't know if you guys have any questions or <disfmarker>
